Bacterial_spot.Cause: Bacterial disease caused by Bacterial spot (Xanthomonas spp.) under warm, wet conditions; seed-borne and spread by rain splash and contaminated tools. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
Bacterial_spot.Symptoms: Small water-soaked circular spots on leaves turning dark brown with yellow halo; raised or scab-like spots on fruit. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
Precautions: Use certified disease-free seed or transplants.
Avoid overhead irrigation and minimise leaf wetness duration.
Disinfect greenhouse/field tools and avoid handling wet plants.

Chemical: Apply copper-based bactericides early in disease development. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
Organic: Eliminate infected plants, practise crop rotation, maintain good airflow.

Early_blight.Cause: Fungal disease caused by Early blight (Alternaria solani or A. tomatophila) that survives in crop debris and infects tomato foliage and fruit under warm, humid conditions. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}
Early_blight.Symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings (‘target-like’) on older leaves near soil line; leaves yellow & drop; fruit may have leathery sunken spots. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}
Precautions: Mulch soil and avoid contact between foliage and soil.
Space plants well to enhance air circulation, and remove lower leaves near soil.
Rotate crops and destroy infected plant debris.

Chemical: Fungicide applications at first sign of lesions; follow label instructions.
Organic: Use organic fungicidal sprays, compost and healthy-plant practices.

Late_blight.Cause: Oomycete disease caused by Late blight (Phytophthora infestans) favoured by cool, moist weather; rapidly destructive to leaves, stems and fruit. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
Late_blight.Symptoms: Water-soaked irregular lesions on leaves often with white sporulation underneath; dark lesions on fruit, rapid plant collapse. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}
Precautions: Avoid planting tomato near potato crops in high-risk regions.
Ensure good drainage and avoid overhead watering; remove infected plants immediately.
Monitor weather and apply protectant fungicides pre-emptively.

Chemical: Apply protectant/systemic fungicides early; repeat under wet conditions.
Organic: Remove and destroy infected foliage and fruit; use resistant varieties.

Leaf_Mold.Cause: Fungal disease commonly called Leaf mold in tomato (caused by Passalora fulva formerly Fulvia fulva) that develops under high humidity and dew, especially in greenhouse or sheltered conditions.
Leaf_Mold.Symptoms: Yellow patches on upper leaf surface, greenish or olive-gray felt on underside, leaves may curl and drop; fruit may remain unaffected initially.
Precautions: Ensure good ventilation in greenhouse, avoid high humidity and condensation on leaves.
Water at soil level, avoid wetting foliage; remove affected leaves early.
Sanitise greenhouse and avoid reuse of infected equipment or surfaces.

Chemical: Fungicide sprays effective against leaf mold; apply at first signs.
Organic: Maintain moderate humidity, remove infected leaves and practise sanitation.

Septoria_leaf_spot.Cause: Fungal disease caused by Septoria leaf spot (Septoria lycopersici) that overwinters in debris and infects lower leaves under warm, wet conditions. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}
Septoria_leaf_spot.Symptoms: Small, circular grey spots with dark margins on lower leaves; black fruiting bodies (pycnidia) often visible; leaves turn yellow and drop. :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}
Precautions: Avoid overhead irrigation; mulch soil; remove and destroy affected lower leaves.
Ensure good spacing and airflow; rotate crops away from tomato or nightshades.
Clean stakes, cages and supports between seasons.

Chemical: Apply fungicide when large number of lower leaves are infected; reduce canopy density.
Organic: Use compost mulch and organic sprays; practise sanitation and rotate crops.

Spider_mites.Cause: Infestation by two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae) or other mite species, not a pathogen but a pest causing leaf damage and predisposition to disease.
Spider_mites.Symptoms: Fine webbing on undersides of leaves, stippling or yellowing of leaves, leaf curling, leaf drop, reduced vigor and yield.
Precautions: Monitor underside of leaves for mites; use miticide or biological control when threshold exceeded.
Maintain good plant vigor with proper water and nutrient supply; avoid excess heat and dryness which favour mites.
Encourage predatory mites and spiders, keep greenhouse environment stable.

Chemical: Apply selective miticides or insecticidal oils according to label.
Organic: Spray neem oil or insecticidal soap; introduce predatory mites; ensure good humidity management.

Target_Spot.Cause: Fungal disease known as Target spot (Corynespora cassiicola) in tomato that creates distinct round lesions often with light centre and dark border; infections come from old crop debris and high humidity in protected environments.
Target_Spot.Symptoms: Round brown lesions on leaves and stems with light central zone and dark border (‘target’ appearance); lesions may merge and cause large dead patches; fruit may show sunken spots.
Precautions: Remove old debris and practise crop rotation; avoid dense planting and ensure airflow.
Space plants and manage humidity; disinfect supports and tools.
Irrigate at the base and avoid water splash from soil to leaves.

Chemical: Apply fungicide at early onset and repeat under favourable conditions for disease spread.
Organic: Use bio-fungicide sprays early; maintain healthy plant growth and remove infected material.

Tomato_mosaic_virus.Cause: Viral disease caused by Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV) transmitted via seed, tools and handling; causes mottling and deformation in tomato plants. :contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}
Tomato_mosaic_virus.Symptoms: Mottled yellow and dark green leaves, blister-like raised patches, leaf distortion, stunting, fruit may have necrotic spots or internal browning. :contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}
Precautions: Use virus-free seed; sanitise tools and hands; restrict tobacco handling near tomatoes.
Remove and destroy infected plants; avoid planting near infected crops.
Practice good hygiene in greenhouse or field operations.

Chemical: No cure once infected; focus on prevention and removal of infected plants.
Organic: Use resistant varieties, maintain plant vigor and practise strict sanitation.

Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.Cause: Viral disease caused by Tomato yellow leaf curl virus (TYLCV) transmitted by whitefly (Bemisia tabaci); highly damaging especially in tropical/sub-tropical regions. :contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}
Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.Symptoms: New leaves small, thicken, curl upward and inward; leaves pale or yellow between veins; plants stunted, yields drastically reduced though fruits may appear few or deformed. :contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}
Precautions: Use whitefly-free transplants, screen greenhouses and monitor whitefly populations.
Use reflective mulches or barrier crops; remove weeds and alternate whitefly hosts.
Use resistant varieties where available; practise crop rotation and isolation of new plantings.

Chemical: No curative chemical for virus; manage vector and remove infected plants promptly.
Organic: Use biocontrol for whiteflies, use reflective mulches; maintain plant health and avoid stress.

healthy.Cause: No major disease, pest or physiological stress detected; plant is growing under optimal conditions.
healthy.Symptoms: Uniform green leaves with no lesions, good branching and fruit set, no visible spots or deformities.
Precautions: Maintain good soil fertility and balanced irrigation.
Inspect regularly for early signs of pests or disease; practise crop hygiene and rotate crops.
Ensure proper spacing, support plants and avoid plant stress.

Chemical: No treatment required other than standard preventive care.
Organic: Use compost or vermicompost for soil health; apply neem or botanical sprays periodically as preventive protection.
